Title: Object: Papyrus Ramesseum 17
Description: P. Ramesseum 17, Frame 2. Papyrus written on the recto and on the verso in hieratic script. The recto contains a magical text for protection for the epagomenal days at the turn of the year and other matters, and on the verso there is a continuation of this text. The text is written in horizontal with some vertical lines. This frame contains Fragments A-D. The papyrus was a half-height roll. The papyrus is part of the collection of papyri found with a bundle of pens in a chest from a plundered late 13th dynasty tomb under the Ramesseum, apparently belonging to someone like a lector priest. Two of the papyri from the chest are in the Egyptian Museum Berlin (P. Ramesseum A and D); the objects are in the Fitzwilliam Museum Cambridge and the Manchester Museum. The papyri are very fragile, apparently due to dampness in the tomb-shaft. This papyrus was mounted on sheets of gelatin by Hugo Ibscher.
Curator's comments: P. Ramesseum 17 Fragments A-D of Frame 2. A. H. Gardiner, The Ramesseum Papyri (Oxford: Oxford University Press 1955), 16 (no published photograph or transcription). On the conservation of the papyri: B. Leach, 'A conservation history of the Ramesseum Papyri', JEA 92 (2006), 225-40. On the tomb: R. B. Parkinson, Reading Ancient Egyptian Poetry: Among Other Histories (Chichester and Malden: Wiley-Blackwell 2009), 138-72.
Bibliographic references: Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (381065) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/381065)
Meyrat 2019 / Les papyrus magiques du Ramesseum. Recherches sur une bibliothèque privée de la fin du Moyen Empire (162–174, 376–395)
